intro: Sisyrinchium lateriflorum, commonly known as the sideflower blue-eyed grass, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the family Poaceae, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, grass-like stems and small, showy blue or purple flowers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as meadows and rocky slopes. Its flowers are arranged in clusters along the sides of the stems, giving it its common name. Sisyrinchium lateriflorum is often found in regions with well-drained soils and is adapted to dry, arid environments.
